Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Single Quantum Dots via 2-Photon Excitation

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Lay Abstract

EAGER: Single Quantum Dots via 2-Photon Excitation
Selvin, Paul R.


Intellectual merit. A two-photon fluorescence microscope will be used to excite individual quantum dots (q-dots), attached to in vitro and in vivo biological specimens. Eventually, the aim is to demonstrate super-accuracy and super-resolution, i.e. accuracy and resolution beyond the diffraction limit of the microscope (< 10 nm) using the methods that will be developed. Two-photon excitation has been shown to be incredibly useful as a means to obtain simultaneous resolution in x, y, and z directions (using the technique known as confocal microscopy), to minimize the effect of light scattering, and to excite multiple fluorophores simultaneously with a single excitation wavelength of light. One-photon excitation of q-dots has already been extremely useful as a means to achieve very bright q-dot emission, long photostability, and the accuracy to visualize individual q-dots at the single-molecule level. In this project, preliminary results indicate that individual q-dots can also be easily visualized with two-photon microscopy under enhanced conditions that rely on extremely low light intensities to excite the q-dots. A goal of this project is to optimize these conditions for 2-photon excitation under biological conditions in order, for instance, to watch molecular motors move (e.g., kinesin and myosin), or to catch a phage virus in the act of infecting a bacterium. The PI has obtained promising preliminary results with wide-field excitation (i.e., not focusing the light down to a diffraction-limited spot) but without a confocal effect needed for z-resolution. To obtain z-resolution, the researchers will repeat the usual methodology but will enhance it in two important ways. First, a highly sensitive charge-coupled detector (CCD) camera will be used to increase the speed of image acquisition. Second, a spatial light modulator will be used to hit the sample with a 10 × 10 array of near-diffraction limited spots, further increasing speed and also permitting super-accuracy and super-resolution in all three spatial dimensions.

Broader impacts. The broader goals of the project are to enable new biological discovery through the development and biological application of two-photon excitation of individual q-dots. Many of the techniques are (or potentially will become) extremely simple. Therefore, it is anticipated that the project will result in generalized techniques that will be widely available to many laboratories interested in visualizing single molecules in living cells and other biological specimens. The project will also enhance the training and expertise of the undergraduates and graduate students who will be involved in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to employ an existing two-photon laser-microscope setup to image biological specimens at a resolution and accuracy not previously achievable, using individual quantum dots as markers. A quantum dot is a tiny semiconductor whose excitons (an electron bound to an electron hole) are confined in all three spatial dimensions. When the laser light illuminates the quantum dot, an exciton is formed, the quantum dot emits a photon, and the microscope can image its precise location in three dimensions. By attaching the quantum dots to biological specimens, we were able to track the motion of the molecular motors that move cargo around inside cells and watch Phage λ (a bacterial virus) infect E. coli. A major goal of this project was to image breast cancer cells with unprecedented resolution and accuracy.

We succeeded in locating, with 2-nm accuracy, the position of quantum dots attached to biological molecules. To get an idea of the accuracy of 2-nm localization, an average virus is about 30 nm to 50 nm in diameter, and a single strand of DNA is about 2.5 nm. We demonstrated this enhanced resolution in breast cancer cells in two dimensions and are extending this super-resolution to three dimensions. We have achieved preliminary results and have a paper reporting these results currently under review.

We demonstrated for the first time that a single quantum dot could be excited by a 2-photon light source and its emission detected and localized to a three-dimensional accuracy of 2 nm. The amount of power needed is surprisingly low, which has a number of advantages. Other researchers having a 2-photon laser and microscope should be able to employ this technique on other substances. We are in the process of commercializing this technology, having filed a patent application on June 27, 2013.

Further, five graduate students (two of whom obtained PhD’s during the course of the project) and two postdoctoral researchers were trained in state-of-the-art fluorescence microscopy and fundamental biophysics research as a result of this project.
